study_identification.author_journal_year: Elad et al., Human Brain Mapping, 2021
study_identification.title: Improving the predictive potential of diffusion MRI in schizophrenia using normative models -Towards subject-level classification

study_characteristics.study_objective: To evaluate the predictive power of features derived from a normative modeling approach and compare it with the predictive power of raw dMRI values serving as features for schizophrenia classification.

dataset_name.reason: The paper states that the data was collated from 13 different sites.
dataset_name.supporting_text: dMRI data were collated from 13 different sites across a number of separate studies.

hc_n.reason: The paper clearly states the number of healthy controls.

hc_age.reason: The paper provides the mean and standard deviation of the age of healthy controls.

hc_sex.reason: The paper provides the number and percentage of male healthy controls.

analysis_level.supporting_text: in 18 white matter regions of interest (ROIs)

preprocessing_pipeline.reason: The paper mentions the use of FSL's DTIFIT and ANTs registration.
preprocessing_pipeline.supporting_text: The harmonized data were fitted using FSL's DTIFIT (Behrens et al., 2003) to the DTI model, from which FA was derived...The FA image of each subject was registered to the FA IIT template using ANTs registration (Avants et al., 2011)

quality_checking.reason: The paper does not mention any quality checking procedures.

quality_checking_detail.reason: The paper does not mention any quality checking procedures.

site_effect_handling.reason: The paper mentions retrospective harmonization to remove site-related differences.
site_effect_handling.supporting_text: The single shell dMRI data followed a standardized preprocessing protocol and were harmonized across sites to remove site-related differences using retrospective harmonization (Karayumak et al., 2019; Ning et al., 2020).

site_effect_handling_detail.reason: The paper explains that the harmonization procedure was evaluated by assessing between-site differences.
site_effect_handling_detail.supporting_text: In particular, Cetin-Karayumak et al. (2020) evaluated the performance of the harmonization procedure by using unpaired t tests to assess between-site differences and showed that statistical differences between matched controls across sites were removed after harmonization (see Figure S2 in Cetin-Karayumak et al., 2020).

model_origin.reason: The paper describes the creation of a new normative model.
model_origin.supporting_text: Here, we take a step towards subject-level inferences by investigating the application of the normative modeling approach on this dataset. We first generate a normative model by estimating age- and sex-adjusted z -scores from standard (FA) and advanced (Free-water) dMRI measures in 18 white matter regions of interest (ROIs).

model_origin_detail.reason: The paper states that a new normative model was generated.
model_origin_detail.supporting_text: We first generate a normative model by estimating age- and sex-adjusted z -scores from standard (FA) and advanced (Free-water) dMRI measures in 18 white matter regions of interest (ROIs).

modeling_method.reason: The paper describes the use of the Nadaraya-Watson estimator.
modeling_method.supporting_text: To do so, we used the NadarayaWatson (NW) estimator (Nadaraya, 1964; Watson, 1964) with a Gaussian kernel,

software_tool.reason: The paper does not mention any specific software tool for normative modeling.

response_variable.reason: The paper specifies FA, FAt, and FW as response variables.
response_variable.supporting_text: For each tract, mean FA, FAt and FW were computed across all voxels traversing the fiber bundle.

predictor_variables.reason: The paper states that age and sex were used as predictor variables.
predictor_variables.supporting_text: To control for confounding factors resulting from age and sex differences, we represented the normative range in each ROI by an age specific weighted mean, c mh , and standard deviation, b σ 2 h , for each sex separately.

predictor_effects.reason: The paper does not specify whether the predictor variables were modeled as fixed or random effects.

nm_vldtn_handle_ns.reason: The paper mentions controlling for age and sex, which can be considered nuisance variables. However, it does not provide a comprehensive discussion on handling other potential nuisance structures.
nm_vldtn_handle_ns.supporting_text: To control for confounding factors resulting from age and sex differences, we represented the normative range in each ROI by an age specific weighted mean, c mh , and standard deviation, b σ 2 h , for each sex separately.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.reason: The paper uses a leave-one-out approach for validation within the control group.
nm_vldtn_same_domain_nonindep.supporting_text: As a result, for each subject, and for each dMRI value (FA, FAt, or FW), we obtained a vector with 18 z -scores (for 17 tracts + white matter skeleton) representing deviation from the normative model.

nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.reason: The paper uses a 10-fold cross-validation procedure to validate the prediction models.
nm_vldtn_same_domain_indep.supporting_text: Prediction performance of the estimated models was validated using a 10-fold cross-validation procedure.

nm_vldtn_diff_domain.reason: The paper does not mention validation on a different domain.

clinical_dataset.reason: The paper states that the dataset includes individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia-spectrum disorder.
clinical_dataset.supporting_text: which includes 601 individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia-spectrum disorder across multiple illness stages

clinical_groups_n.reason: The paper states the number of individuals in the clinical group.

clinical_groups_age.reason: The paper provides the mean and standard deviation of the age of the clinical group.

clinical_groups_sex.reason: The paper provides the number and percentage of males in the clinical group.

deviation_metric.reason: The paper describes the use of z-scores to quantify deviation.
deviation_metric.supporting_text: The deviation of every individual diagnosed with schizophrenia from the normative atlas, in each ROI, was captured by a z -score

clinical_application_and_analysis.association_analysis: The study used Welch's t-tests and Wilcoxon rank-sum tests for group comparisons, and logistic regression with ridge regularization for prediction modeling. The performance of the prediction models was evaluated using the area under the receiver operator curve (AUC).
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_brief: The use of the complete distribution of deviations from the normative range of each individual as an input to a binary classifier improves the predictive performance for all tested measures (FA, FAt, FW).
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_findings_detailed: The study found that using the complete distribution of deviations from a normative model improves subject-level classification of schizophrenia from dMRI data. While extreme deviations were not highly predictive, combining the full range of z-scores across multiple white matter tracts and multiple dMRI measures (FA, FAt, and FW) yielded the best classification performance (AUC = 0.726). This suggests that schizophrenia is characterized by subtle, distributed white matter abnormalities rather than large focal ones.
clinical_application_and_analysis.key_limitations: The study's limitations include the use of retrospectively harmonized data from non-state-of-the-art acquisition protocols, the lack of accounting for treatment and comorbidity heterogeneity, the need to test for specificity against other psychotic disorders, and the absence of an investigation into the relationship between brain abnormalities and clinical symptoms.
clinical_application_and_analysis.application_notes: The authors suggest that their findings can serve as an early step in the development of a classification scheme that involves schizophrenia and therefore aid in subject-level classification. They also propose that including additional measures and developing more elaborate normative models could further improve prediction performance.

general_notes.general_notes: The paper provides a thorough investigation of the predictive potential of normative modeling in schizophrenia using a large, multi-site dMRI dataset. The use of both standard and advanced dMRI measures, as well as the comparison of different feature sets for classification, are notable strengths of the study.
